•Ultra violet (comes from the sun)
•X-rays
•Gamma rays

For those who don't understand:
Microwaves shake molecules in your food, causing friction which heats food. Metal contains electrons which also react with microwave energy. Think of how a thunderstorm works: electrons rub together and create friction, thus building an extremely high voltage which is released as lightning. Basically, you're creating a miniature thunderstorm inside the microwave.

It's not "heat" escaping. Heat is infrared radiation, this is microwave radiation. It heats up food not because it is hot, but because the microwave is set to the exact resonant frequency of a water molecule. When the waves hit water, the molecules resonate (vibrate). This increased kinetic energy of the water molecules transfers to the other molecules by conduction, and since heat is the kinetic energy of molecules, the food heats up. But anything without water will not heat up. So what you've done is allowed the microwaves to escape instead of concentrating them within the oven.

Heat does not travel as a particle. However all photons from all electromagnetic (EM) waves have certain kinetic energies associated with them. Only once the atoms in an object absorb energy from EM radiation can it be measured as temperature or heat. Its based on collisions with electrons, molecules, etc. So while the microwaves do not bounce heat around, the materials or food being bombarded by the waves do increase in energy, temperature, and heat. (This reminds me of the confusion around E=MC^2 relating to photons. That's not the full equation, it's abbreviated. Science Asylum has a great video on this. Light has no mass (so how does M fit into equation? well...) but light DOES have energy, and momentum) So while photons don't have mass, they do have energy and momentum which allows molecules to increase or decrease in energy. The EM wave nature of the microwaves have oscillating positive + and negative - peaks, they are able to interact and excite polar + - water molecules very easily. This is how food is energized and cooked. The insulation of the confined space helps retain the heat via lack of convection. Once food is out in the open air (as long as the temp is lower than the food's temp) the hot boundary layer of air surrounded the food can be blown or removed and cool the food. Infrared cookers work well, but do not cook food as evenly, and wouldn't be the same process or ease as a microwave.

Some high quality devices can use a metal shield to protect itself from this problem just like how the microwave uses the same concept to contain it. Perfect metal to electromagnetic wave = mirror.  lossy metal to electromagnetic wave = absorber. Plastic to electromagnetic wave = lens / glass.
